title: Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: The book, Estrogen Matters, discusses the polarizing and confusing topic of hormone replacement therapy for women suffering with symptoms of menopause. The authors make a compelling case that most women benefit greatly from being on postmenopausal hormone replacement therapy, and can do so without increasing their risk of breast cancer. The history of HRT, the impact of the Women’s Health Initiative, and each of the clinical conditions for which HRT should be considered, such as cardiovascular disease and neurodegenerative disease, and osteoporosis, are also covered.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy and Breast Cancer
content: The perception that estrogen causes a 25% increase in breast cancer is discussed, with the authors arguing that this is a misunderstanding of absolute vs. relative risk. The truth about progesterone and cancer risk, and the best types of estrogen and progesterone to be taking are also discussed.

title: Benefits of Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: The benefits of HRT on heart disease, bone health, and the potential to reduce the risk of colon cancer and diabetes are discussed. The ideal time to start HRT and the risks associated with HRT are also covered.

title: Downsides and Controversies of Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: The downsides of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) and how to approach a doctor who may already have a very strong point of view about HRT are discussed. The authors also discuss the kind of research that needs to be done to answer the remaining questions about the benefits and risks of HRT.

title: Hair Restoration
content: The science behind male and female pattern hair loss, and what that tells us about prevention and restoration is discussed. Insights into what works and what doesn’t in terms of the non-surgical treatment options are shared.

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Latest insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting.

title: Impact of stress on physical and emotional health
content: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health.

title: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, prevention strategies
content: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Training principles for longevity.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease
content: Preventing cardiovascular disease: the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life
content: Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life.

title: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy
content: The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more.

title: Hair loss prevention and restoration
content: Discusses both male and female pattern hair loss, the science behind what drives it, and what that tells us about prevention and restoration. Insights into what works and what doesn’t in terms of the non-surgical treatment options. The importance of seeing a hair specialist. Impact of scalp health and inflammation on hair growth, how to pick and apply shampoo and conditioner, and how to avoid and treat hair breakage.

title: Estrogen Matters
content: The background of Carol and Avrum, and the impetus for writing Estrogen Matters. The major assumption dealing with breast cancer is that estrogen causes breast cancer, and it doesn’t. Almost everything we’ve done in the treatment of breast cancer is based on that assumption so that women have been denied estrogen for at least the last 30 years. . . and the result is that many women have been hurt by being denied that medicine.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: Hormone replacement therapy in women has a significant time course. The number of women with breast cancer and men with prostate cancer is approximately comparable in the United States. The medical establishment made the false leap that testosterone is responsible for prostate cancer and estrogen is therefore responsible for breast cancer. Prostate cancer was treated initially by castration of the testicle, it doesn’t cure it, but it helps in some cases. Women were castrated by removal of the ovaries to eliminate estrogen to treat breast cancer, it helps in some cases, but not many. If the adrenal gland removal didn’t work, we then would take out the anterior pituitary gland at the base of the brain because that gland produces a hormone that stimulates either the ovary or the testicle to make the responsible hormone. They even started to prophylactically remove the ovaries of those who previously had breast cancer to try to keep it from coming back.

title: Estrogen and Menopause
content: Estrogen can relieve the symptoms of menopause which include hot flashes, night sweats, palpitations, cognitive decline, joint pains, sleep disturbances, and depression. It was suggested that estrogen is also capable of reducing significant heart disease by up to 50%. Women have hormones such as luteinizing hormone, follicle stimulating hormone and they are coming out of the pituitary and telling the ovaries to make yet more hormones. Then suddenly, during menopause, their production seem to drop off a cliff.

title: Breast Cancer vs Heart Disease
content: Estrogen can significantly decrease the risk of heart disease. However, many women believe that old women die of heart disease, young women die of breast cancer. So the women often say they’d rather not take estrogen if estrogen causes breast cancer. But more than that, in every decade of a woman’s life, the incidence of death from heart disease is greater than the incidence of death from breast cancer. Women are 10 times more likely to die from heart disease than breast cancer. Women are ~5 times more likely to get heart disease than breast cancer.

title: Symptoms of Menopause
content: Many of the symptoms that women begin to develop in their 40s, they don’t associate with menopause. Muscle pain sends them to rheumatologists and depression sends them to therapists and fighting with their spouses sends them to family therapy. And they don’t think that their changes of menopause might be involved.

title: Personal Stories
content: A woman got breast cancer at age 45. She was treated with chemotherapy and at the same time she went into menopause. She was very symptomatic with night sweats, difficulty sleeping, joint pains, palpitations. She eventually was put on HRT and she was back to normal in about two weeks. Another woman who had survived ER/PR-positive breast cancer underwent a hysterectomy, oophorectomy and mastectomies. She described a feeling of fog.

title: Chemotherapy and Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: Once the chemo is done, you will feel better. Three years after the chemo, she felt worse. It finally occurred to her and to her husband that maybe this had something to do with the fact that at the age of 42, overnight she lost every sex hormone in her body. She couldn’t find any doctor on the planet who would prescribe hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to her, because as a breast cancer survivor who’s ER/PR-positive, how could you do such a thing? Though she did eventually find someone who was willing to give her a trial. She felt immediately better. Within weeks she felt like she got her life back. By the time Peter met her, she was on a “very clever regimen”: Topical estriol (not estradiol), She didn’t need progesterone (because she had hysterectomy), Physiologic replacement of testosterone (up to about half a nanogram per deciliter level).

title: Changing Perceptions of HRT and the Women’s Health Initiative
content: The changing perceptions of HRT, the impact of the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI), and the problems with the WHI. Picking up in the 1950-1960s, Robert Wilson’s book, Feminine Forever, has encouraged many women to get on estrogen. Premarin was the primary source of estrogen. Premarin, acronym for pregnant mare urine, is still the most used form of estrogen today. In the early 1970s, there was a sharp rise in uterine cancer. Turns out, estrogen, given alone, can increase uterine cancer by 5-fold. So estrogen replacement fell off dramatically. In the late 1970s, it was learned that progesterone together with estrogen, nullified the risk of uterine cancer, so HRT started to increase again. It continued that way until about 2002 when it was estimated that about 16 million women in the United States were taking HRT. Either estrogen alone if they didn’t have a uterus, or the combination, if they did have a uterus. That constituted about 22% of the appropriate age population in the US. By 2004, HRT use was down from 22% to 10% of age appropriate population. By 2010, HRT use fell to 5%. This was largely due to the first publication of the Women’s Health Initiative.

title: Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) Study
content: Nurses’ Health Study was published in 1995. ~120,000 nurses were followed for 30 years. Found that women who took HRT for 5, 10, or 15 years had no increased risk of breast cancer. Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) study was initiated in 1996, and first published in 2002. The theoretical rationale for the study was NOT to see whether it increased breast cancer… what they wanted to see is did it really have a beneficial effect on the heart and the brain and the bones. The WHI had two separate studies: 1) Nutritional study 2) Hormone replacement study.

title: Problems with the Hormone Replacement Arm of the WHI
content: The study participants: Avg age was 63 (which is 10 years after menopause), 70% were very overweight or obese, >50% were smokers, Many had hypertension. This was not an ideal, healthy sample, by any means. For economic reasons, it made sense to choose an older population. But this was never a normal population, and as soon as the study came out in 2002, it was immediately extrapolated to all women everywhere. Exclusion of symptomatic women: women who were especially symptomatic were excluded. The reasoning being is that there was a concern that if you took in women who had serious vasomotor symptoms and they were randomized to the placebo, your drop-out rate would be too high. That would be alright, if you acknowledge that up front, says Avrum, but the WHI reported “findings” that HRT had absolutely no benefit on quality of life. The reason they found that is because women who were significantly symptomatic were excluded.

title: Estrogen and Breast Cancer Risk
content: A very common question Peter gets from women: Doesn’t HRT increase the risk of breast cancer by 25%? Where did this number come from? 2013 JAMA paper: Menopausal Hormone Therapy and Health Outcomes During the Intervention and Extended Poststopping Phases of the Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Trials (Manson et al., 2013). 2015 JAMA paper: Breast Cancer After Use of Estrogen Plus Progestin and Estrogen Alone, Analyses of Data From 2 Women’s Health Initiative Randomized Clinical Trials (Chlebowski, et al., 2015). Randomization of the study: You had two cohorts of women. Cohort #1: You had women who had already undergone a hysterectomy and they were randomized to estrogen (CEE, conjugated equine estrogen) or placebo. Cohort #2: And women whose uterus was still in place were randomized to CEE plus MPA (medroxyprogesterone acetate) versus a placebo. Randomization was one-to-one throughout. Results: The women in cohort 1, those that were randomized to just estrogen, had no increased risk of breast cancer. They actually had a 21% decreased risk, but it was not statistically significant. The women in cohort 2, those that received both estrogen and progesterone, there was a reported 26% increase in risk of breast cancer compared to placebo. However, it also wasn’t statistically significant… “So by scientific standards, we think that could have been caused by chance alone.” P-value was below .05.

title: Understanding Risk Factors
content: Eating a grapefruit doubles my risk of bunions. If the numbers jumped from one person to two persons out of a hundred or out of a thousand, that’s not a very big thing. If the numbers double from 500 to 1000 in a group of 10,000, then we might have a finding we should be paying attention to.

title: Progesterone and Cancer Risk
content: When looking at WHI data, the women you got both progesterone and estrogen had an increased risk in breast cancer compared to those that just got estrogen. The increased risks seen with the combination was not statistically significant, did not hold up, and was due largely a problem with the control group. There are now forms of progesterone, which are not synthetic, that are now being advised and used; and thus far, have not been associated even with any finding of an increased risk of breast cancer.

title: Progesterone as a Treatment for Breast Cancer
content: In a randomized trial comparing tamoxifen to progesterone in the 1970s, progesterone did a little better than tamoxifen, but because in the dosage used, it was associated with increase fluid retention, and women became nauseated, it lost out to tamoxifen, but it was used to treat breast cancer. There was a study that came out of India that found that giving an injection of progesterone around the time of surgery to remove primary breast cancer, significantly improved the prognosis, and decreased the risk of recurrence.

title: Bioidentical Hormones
content: Bioidentical really refers to estradiol, which is the leading circulating estrogen in a woman’s body. Bioidentical is also used for what is prepared by pharmacists based on prescriptions written by local practitioners where quality control is lacking. Premarin (the most common estrogen medication) is an acronym for pregnant mare urine. It is the longest studied form of estrogen. We, now, have 60 years of data with Premarin. Most of the studies that show the benefit for estrogen are studies that were done on Premarin. Premarin contains at least 10 different forms of estrogen, including some that are the most beneficial forms of estrogen for brain health, which is not present in “bioidentical forms” such as estradiol or estriol.

title: Estrogen and Breast Cancer
content: The blanket assumption is that estrogen causes breast cancer. However, to the contrary, as women get older and have lower estrogen levels, the rates of breast cancer increase. The best answer I can give is we think we understand the environment that is friendly to a cancer, which is the environment in which the cancer develops. We try to change that environment to make it less conducive to the continued growth of the cancer. That means in a low estrogen environment, you might use estrogen because that is now unfriendly to the cancer. In a high estrogen environment, you might remove estrogen.

title: Women’s Health Initiative Findings
content: First publication of results (2002): Risks and benefits of estrogen plus progestin in healthy postmenopausal women: Principal results From the Women’s Health Initiative randomized controlled trial. Reported findings: The combination of estrogen and progesterone increases the risk of breast cancer. Increases the risk of heart attacks. Increases the risk of cognitive decline. Decreases the risk of colon cancer. Helps protect the bones.

title: Benefits of HRT
content: This study by Nananda Col showed that if every woman in the United States do hormone replacement therapy (HRT) it would increase the median survival of women by 3.3 years in this country. This report suggests tens of thousands of women died prematurely as a result of being taken off hormone therapy.

title: HRT and Alzheimer’s Disease
content: Women are two times more likely to die of Alzheimer’s disease than men. The one potential preventive medication is estrogen which can reduce the incidence of Alzheimer’s disease by between 20 and 50% depending upon the study you look at.

title: HRT and Heart Disease
content: The report from the 2002 WHI suggested HRT increased risk of heart disease. However, there is no increased risk if a woman begins HRT at the time of menopause. . .with no preexisting cardiac vascular disease.

title: HRT and Bone Health
content: We now know that as many women in the United States will die each year of a hip fracture as the number who will die of breast cancer.

title: Hip Fracture and Mortality
content: Approximately 21% of women who fracture their hip will die within a year of the hip fracture. That number is approximately 40,000, which is the number of women who die in this country of breast cancer every year.

title: Osteoporosis and its Treatments
content: Looking at bone mineral density is the way we currently test for osteoporosis. However, bone mineral density a poor substitute but it’s the best we have. The true test is how much a bone can be flexed before it snaps. Current treatments for osteoporosis include Calcium and vitamin D, Bisphosphonates, and Estrogen. Studies show estrogen can decrease risk of fracture by up to 50%.

title: Colon Cancer and HRT
content: Colon cancer mortality is not as lethal as pancreatic or lung cancer but it is more lethal than breast cancer. A number of significant studies have shown that Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) does indeed reduce the risk of colon cancer. Estrogen protects against the growth of cancerous cells in the colon.

title: Diabetes and HRT
content: Diabetes seems to decrease when taking estrogen. However, more studies are needed before reaching a conclusion.

title: Downsides of Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: The downsides of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) include Pulmonary embolism (blockage of an artery in the lungs) resulting from a venous thromboembolism (blood clot) and Gallstones. The risk of pulmonary embolism is small but significant enough that if the patient has a condition or is taking something that can predispose to that kind of clot, it must be a consideration before somebody starts on hormones.

title: Estriol and Testosterone
content: We don’t have large scale studies on estriol, so caution is advised. Testosterone has been associated with the development of breast cancer.

title: Future Research on HRT
content: HRT seems to have an impact on 80-85% of the diseases that lead to death in women including, but not limited to: Cancer, Atherosclerosis (all of the cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases), Alzheimer’s disease, Bone fractures. However, the cost and complexity of repeating a study of the magnitude of the Women's Health Initiative is standing in the way.

title: Racial Differences in HRT
content: There are different racial predispositions to breast cancer. However, to the best of our knowledge, no studies suggest that Caucasian, African-American, Hispanic, Asian women might actually benefit or be harmed differentially from hormones.

title: Book Discussion on Health Literature
content: The book is laid out with a time course of the literature of the studies, making it an important exercise. The goal was to make the book readable enough for lay readers, especially for women personally concerned about health issues. It provides the sources and information for those who want to know in more detail what the science shows.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy Study
content: A paper written in 2009 discusses Hormone Replacement Therapy, Real Concerns and False Alarms. The paper includes data and is made enjoyable to read with a touch of personality.

title: HRT after Breast Cancer Diagnosis
content: The question of Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) after a diagnosis of breast cancer is still open without an obvious conclusion. However, some evidence suggests it might not be harmful, and could be beneficial. For example, getting pregnant after having a diagnosis of breast cancer does not compromise the prognosis. There are approximately 15 studies on the subject and only 1 of them showed an increase in breast cancer risk.

title: HRT Study on Breast Cancer Patients
content: A study was conducted administering HRT to patients who had had breast cancer. Over 14 years, the study showed no increased risks of local recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, or distant recurrence among the women who took hormones, compared to the women who didn’t, when they were matched stage for stage.
